reviewText:
Lost Lands: A Hidden Object Adventure has received quite a lot of negative reviews during the first days after it was released, and this because of 2 main reasons: on one hand, the game had a lot of bugs of various severity (from typos or bad translations to crashes, achievements unlocking and the impossibility to start the game on some systems); on the other hand, the game featured two achievements that were obtainable only by investing a huge amount of real money (around $200) that attracted the anger of a lot of people, including myself.

However, the feedback that the community received from the developers is quite impressive – not only they changed the paid achievements but they also started to fix the major bugs and they are currently working on fixing the minor issues too, and all this in a very short period of time.

The game itself is not entirely bad, it’s quite repetitive but at the same time it was designed to hook you up, just like the standard smartphone/Facebook games. The fact that you have a limit to the actions you can do in one play session might or might not make you revisit the game next day, to progress some more.

The gameplay consists mainly in solving hidden object scenes that award some items used to complete the quests or collections or unlock additional bonuses. The fact that you have a most 15 locations (depending on your level, 1 - 15) that you visit over and over again adds to the monotony of the game – but on the bright side, after you solve 3-4 times the same hidden object scene, you learn exactly where all the objects are which makes it much easier afterwards.

Additionally, you can receive some chests from killing mobs, but unlocking them proves to be a real challenge – the puzzles are timed and most often of high difficulty.

For those that want to 1-click solve a chest puzzle or a hidden object scene, there is an in-game shop from which they can buy items in exchange for real money. The shop also provides all the objects needed for unlocking new locations or completing the collections. However, in comparison with most of the other pay-to-win games, all these items can be acquired also by playing the game, without spending a cent of real money, but of course these drop in small amounts so one is expected to invest a lot of patience and time to finish this game.

The objects in the hidden object scenes and the whole artwork is designed in the style of Artifex Mundi games, meaning that overall the artwork is nice and with vibrant colors; the objects are quite visible but at the same time hidden strategically so that they blend perfectly into the background, making them harder to be spotted, which is by definition one of the characteristics of this genre.

At the moment of writing this review, I think that the biggest complaint from the community remains the long time to achieve 100% - in order to do that one needs to revisit every location a few hundred times and all of this require energy; the energy pool is quite small and limited, allowing you to play only 4-5 hidden object scenes in a single play session - this will probably make people loose interest in the game quite quickly since they will not be able to enjoy the game for more than 10 minutes at once. Hopefully, the game parameters will be adjusted in the future.

I decided to give this game a positive review, not only because it is an enjoyable experience (despite the long grind for 100% achievements) but also because of the constructive attitude from the developers, that are actively working on improving our gaming experience.

reviewText:
Lost Lands: A Hidden Object Adventure is the first game I've played from developer / Publisher FIVE-BN GAMES I've been on a hidden objects game kick lately so I figured I would give it a go.

Pros:
- Free (I have to start with that right?)
- Beautiful scenery and character artwork, I really love it.
- Easy quest story system giving you goals to achieve so you aren't playing blind.
- Multiple hidden object modes, with Pictures, Lists, Silhouettes, and Day/Night
- Plenty of locations
- multiple Chest Minigames
- Steam Achievements
Cons:
- Energy based exploration. (Seriously? What is this Facebook?)
- Bugs that instead of being fixed just included a work around in the changelog. (Really you want me to do bad on purpose to slow the game progress even further, not just once but repeatedly?)
- Energy costs to explore levels rises disproportionably to the rate your energy rises so you can play less the further into the game you progress
- Puzzle variation, Each zone only has 3 places max that each object is placed, so when exploring the same zone over and over as required by the game the objects will always be in the same place.
- Repetitive I don't want to explore the same screen 50+ times if not only do the objects only exist in 3 places but it's always the same objects.
- Level Entry Item cost. Not only do levels require energy to enter many levels require multiple items (Example: Coal) to enter, so to get into said level you need 50 Energy, but oh wait you also need 2 coal go farm this other level for 50 energy each time twice and hope to get a coal each time.
- Game originally introduced with steam achievements you actually had to pay real money to get (not a small amount either.) Those have since been removed but all achievements still are not attainable unless you are willing to do bad at each puzzle over 50 times, with the energy system this is ridiculous.
- Game pace, I don't want to be playing this weeks from now let alone months or years from now. I want to beat it and move on, Current design will take months if not years to complete playing 10 minutes at a time twice a day.

Pro and Con:
- Music, this could be considered a pro because it's relaxing, but there is no variation. Do you really want to listen to this same music for the years it takes you to complete this?

Overall score: 4/10 I am basing this score only in comparison to other hidden object games, and honestly it's only that high because of the amazing artwork. If you can't a non energy based hidden object game or like playing the same facebook game for years try this. If not just buy a better hidden object game.

Given the content I feel I could invest quite a bit of my time in larger chunks, but that pesky energy reserve dwindles fast. Too fast to get anything done for more than a handful of minutes at a time. Especially at low levels.

This is frustrating, because I love, dearly, hidden object games. I understand that this is a free game and that money coming in for the developers efforts is from paying real money for ingame items. I get that. I've played many mobile games with this feature, without ever paying for items due to my patience with them and limited time to access them. However, I think this game could have benefited from a fixed base selling price for revenue, and let the game unlock and develop at its own pace per the player's usage, with additional payments being a luxury or to enhance gameplay, not advance it. I also feel that because there is a crippling limit when not paying for playability that the achievements take far longer than necessary to complete. If the game was more open and already paid for, then working toward each achievement would feel more like an acomplishment than a burden.

I may change my mind later on, giving it more time to develop, before I settle either way definitely. For now though, I find more annoyances and cons than fun to recommend to others. There are some great ideas and an interesting set up here, just executed a little too mobile phone-like for the value that Steam usually carries.

reviewText:
Oddly compelling Hidden Object game.

Level 10, so far it went well for me without using real money to buy in-game stuff. For anyone like me, worried that they'd accidentally buy something; Steam overlay pops up wanting you to confirm the purchase, with a convenient cancel button. Works well for me too. I will probably buy something to support the developer when I'm done with the game (though not more than I'd pay for any other HO game). He deserves some money for the care put into it. And it's fun.

The energy needed to play the scenes recharges at a good rate, and exceeds max while sleeping. Plus, levelling up refills to max (sadly not more if you already have max or more energy).

There are various locations, more and more unlocking as you progress. They are re-used, but as you progress the items to be found get more and more, only a handful to find at a time that are renewed as you find them. I don't think random clicking would get anyone anywhere. On the other hand, objects often enough have the same locations (I have not figured out yet what has the placement change - it's a surprise when they do), so some are easily found if you remember where they are. I do like the way the game does these. (Btw, each scene has a limited time. Not being able to evade that would seriously spoil my fun.)

The graphics are very nice, much care has been taken to create the locations and the map, and put the items to be found into sensible spots.

So far I've seen 3 different modes for hidden object finding: by words, by silhouettes, and by words or silhouettes with only small part of the scene visible (a circle you can move around). Which you get seems to be random (with the quests to do at night - the small-part-only-visible version - it might take several attempts to get that mode).

There are also minigames/puzzles for opening chests with useful stuff. I rather like that (though would enjoy that more without timer).

There is even a point to rummaging around locations for random junk, though the actual hidden objects and the things you're digging out of the locations story-wise don't match.

There's also monsters to beat, special items to put together, and buildings to be repaired, for which you have to find (in the HO locations), or purchase (with in-game gold or gems that you earn by playing) different things. Another nice way to add different activities. Plus, you collect stuff that adds various bonuses, from faster energy recharging to getting more xp from quests. And there are enough free hint/solve items dropped (at least for me - I prefer not to use them if I can help it at all).

The quests you get for progression and unlocking more locations have that 'just one more' effect on me. Maybe for some people it would be hard to resist buying stuff with real money to continue rather than waiting a bit. Only you know how good a grip you have on your wallet. :)

I like this game. I'm a little sorry that it has this many negative reviews, because it's a game that is chill to just take 10 minutes off, and do something that is not very taxing or adrenalinerushing.

People who are looking to play this game from scratch need to look at it in either of two ways.
1. A game that I will spend a ridiculous amount of money on - like really - an obscene amount of money on - to complete it in the fastest way possible.
2. Make it a part of my daily routine for 10-20 minutes every day, and make it a slower progress.

For acheivement hunters: This game will take a while to complete. Not in terms of playtime, because the investment is not really that much, but in terms of real time, where you will daily log on to play this for a short interval.

As of now I have logged into this game daily for 3 months with only 40 hours play as of writing this review. I only have 8% of the acheivements, since they are logged in a wierd way. You proceed in stages, which are tracked in the game's internal acheievement system, so it's not like it will then take me another 27 months to get all the 100% acheivements, but it will definitely take some time, if I want to do it without spending any actual, human money on it.

I have gathered that initially there were quite a few problems regarding acheivements and typoes in the chat that gave the game a rather unprofessional appearance. But this is one of those games where the devs are fixing errors reported by the community.
(For example there is an acheivement that requires for you to spend gems, which are bought with real money. The community didn't like that you had to pay to get acheivements. In response, the game now awards a small amount of gems every 5 consecutive days logged in, and upon levelling up, which makes the acheivement possible without actually spending any money)

This is a good game that you do not just complete overnight. You will need patience and persistence. If you're up for a challenge, do take up the game.

Of course, as an ongoing hidden object game, you will find yourself level grinding during some quests, but that can't be helped in this genre. Overall, it is an excellent game with an interesting cast of characters and enough variety to justify coming back frequently.

The game is designed like a pay to win game but you can actually play the full game without spending a dime.  The energy bar is small and most game sessions you will only get 4 or 5 HOG scenes per play session consisting of about 10 to 20 minutes. However, part of the jackpot of some of your victories is a puzzle chest (about 8 varieties), and very little energy is needed to play those chests. Thus you can usually always end a play session playing a couple puzzle chest extending your play time. The chest themselves are for the most part challenging.

As far as the HOG scenes, the hidden objects are nicely illustrated and all but a couple are named correctly. (flute is misnamed and one object gets a name change 2/3 of the way thorugh, and one oject takes advantage of synonyms), interestingly, since this extended play game involves going to all the HOG scenes (about 15) multiple times it eventually morphs from a  Hidden object game to a memory game.  This is the only HOG I have ever played where I did not mind the timer clock. Eventually it became fun for me to beat the clock at the first stage, trying to remember all the hidden spaces. My guess is that an object will have about four hidey holes within an HOG scene. So its never a matter of replaying an HOG scene and going to the last hidey hole.

The music is excellent, the graphics are great, but the story telling is lame. The way they tried to tell the story did not work at all for me. It bascially felt like they tagged on a story after they created the game world. The story was totally uninvolving and I ususally just clicked through the text.

OTOH, the game achievments and game collections drove me to put dozens and dozens  of hours into this game. If you are a completionist, this game will drive you like no other HOG. However, the designers negleted to put in about 4 game pieces so it is impossible to get 100 % on the game collection part.

The game does have paid transactions if you want to buy energy or gems, but as long as you don't mind waiting for energy to build up there is no reason to spend money on the game. Even the gem and coin spending achievements can be achieved without spending real money as you can get gems once a week by logging in every day.\n\nIf you're are a fan of Facebook type games then you'll love this, if you don't like waiting around for energy to build up then this game isn't for you.

As many people has said before me, this game offers the option to pay real money for gems, which will in turn allow you to buy energy boosters, which will give you energy to keep playing.

But there's something different with this game compared to other pay-to-play games. It's actually NOT pay-to-play if you don't mind waiting, which is my case. There is absolutely nothing in the game that cannot be gained unless you pay money. Everything is accessible.

In my case, I play this game about 10-15 minutes a day. That's all I need to spend all my energy, have a little fun, complete a quest or two, and then that's it. I come back the following day, my energy is full, I spend it, open a few chests, and close the game again. And so on.

Personally, I have absolutely no problem with this type of games, especially if it's not pay-to-win. It doesn't matter if others pay for gems and you don't, because it's not putting them above you, making them stronger than you, or anything. It's a single player game. You go to your pace, and that's it. I don't care if some people has finished the game 15 times faster than I did because they paid real money. I like this game, and I don't mind waiting for energy; I go and play something else once I'm done with my daily energy and that's it.

Plus, and this it important: every time you log in daily (whether you spend all your energy or just log in), you progress in the daily rewards table, and that table gives you 6 gems every 6 days. So stop complaining about real money, you CAN get gems just by logging in. You can get all locations, all items, all achievements for FREE. You just have to play 10-15 minutes a day until you get there.

If you like hidden objects games and don't mind the wait, then this game is very well done, and I plan on getting another from this series once I'm done with this one. It's free to play, so how about you just get it, try it, and judge for yourself?

HOG and puzzle game play is nicely done, and they change the placement of items often enough to ensure playing at the same location many times does not feel stale.

That said, I am never enthusiastic about these kinds of energy based games. You spend 9/10ths of your time waiting for your energy bar to fill up, and even with level up increases, I still only get enough energy to play 5 (very short) rounds before I have to wait again.  This is immersion breaking, and frustrating. I would happily play a purchasable version of this game to bypass that painful mechanic, but as it stands, the only way to avoid constant waiting to continue is through micropurchases, which falls into the trap of feeling extorting. This is the kind of flaw that gives the F2P genre a bad name.

I'm giving this a 'recommend' because it is, overall, a well made game. But I am very unsure how long I will be playing it due to the frustration of the waiting game. And I'd be much quicker to support the makers, monetarily, if it didn't feel like the game style penalizes you if you don't. So its a 'recommend' but with major asterisks.

The game is designed like a pay to win game but you can actually play the full game without spending a dime.  The energy bar is small and most game sessions you will only get 4 or 5 HOG scenes per play session consisting of about 10 to 20 minutes. However, part of the jackpot of some of your victories is a puzzle chest (about 8 varieties), and very little energy is needed to play those chests. Thus you can usually always end a play session playing a couple puzzle chest extending your play time. The chest themselves are for the most part challenging.

As far as the HOG scenes, the hidden objects are nicely illustrated and all but a couple are named correctly. (flute is misnamed and one object gets a name change 2/3 of the way thorugh, and one oject takes advantage of synonyms), interestingly, since this extended play game involves going to all the HOG scenes (about 15) multiple times it eventually morphs from a  Hidden object game to a memory game.  This is the only HOG I have ever played where I did not mind the timer clock. Eventually it became fun for me to beat the clock at the first stage, trying to remember all the hidden spaces. My guess is that an object will have about four hidey holes within an HOG scene. So its never a matter of replaying an HOG scene and going to the last hidey hole.

The music is excellent, the graphics are great, but the story telling is lame. The way they tried to tell the story did not work at all for me. It bascially felt like they tagged on a story after they created the game world. The story was totally uninvolving and I ususally just clicked through the text.

OTOH, the game achievments and game collections drove me to put dozens and dozens  of hours into this game. If you are a completionist, this game will drive you like no other HOG. However, the designers negleted to put in about 4 game pieces so it is impossible to get 100 % on the game collection part.

Hidden objects games should let any type of player spend as much time as they'd like completing a puzzle.  I understand the point of having achievements (thus the 3 stars being on a time limit), but I highly disagree with the player losing completely once the time goes down.  It encourages random clicking along the screen, while making it near impossible for players to look around and also enjoy the art and environment your artsists and designers so lovingly created.\n\nCertain people will always have trouble finding specific objects, until they have begun to recognize and memorize how the objects look.  However, this method greatly punishes new players of this game or genre, while inducing panic in players that might enjoy spending as much time as they like.  I like the art, and the story, and the somewhat integration of resource management, but you don't let all player types play the game as they want.  You don't let players take their time in a game that challenges the mind.  If you did that, you would gain even more fans of this game.
